learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of Workplace Health and Safety laws that impact on the management of OHS.
Demonstrate an understanding of how other Laws impact on the management of OHS.
Identify and apply relevant Laws to the management of OHS.
Demonstrate an understanding of legal principles and processes in the context of OHS.
Ability to communicate legal requirements to relevant stakeholders and to identify when to seek professional legal advice.

assessments.task_description:
Students must attend both days of course delivery and complete workshop activities collaboratively (groups of 3 or 4 students) and report back on completed activities as required.

Active participation is weighted at 5% each day. Participation marks will be pro-rated, to obtain the full 5% you will need to be in the class for the entire day (9:00am – 4:00pm), any absences greater than 30mins will result in a deduction in line with the following:

  • Absent 30mins - 1 hour: maximum of 4 marks
  • Absent 1-2 hours: maximum of 3 marks
  • Absent 2-4 hours: maximum of 2 marks
  • Absent 4+ hours: maximum of 1 marks


If students are absent for medical reasons they will need to liaise directly with the course coordinator to arrange alternative assessment

assessments.task_description:
The Moot Court exercise involves a detailed hypothetical OHS legal case. Students will be allocated specific tasks relating to the hypothetical OHS legal case. 

Students are required to:

Part 1: Plan: students will research their allocated tasks and develop a written plan. [10%]

Part 2: Role Play: students will participate in a role play and deliver an oral presentation based on their allocated task/s for the Moot Court Exercise. [30%] HURDLE

Part 3: Case Review: Students will provide a written case review/reflection for the Moot Court Exercise. [20%]


Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Part 1 and Part 3 submission by Turnitin only by the due date and time. No submission is required for Part 2 (Role Play)

learning_activities.topic:
OHS Law

Workshops on the first weekend will cover:

  1. Introduction to OHS law in Australia;
  2. OHS duties;
  3. Consultation and entry;
  4. Incident Notification;
  5. Risk Management;
  6. Codes of Practice;
  7. Workers' compensation;
  8. Concept of Duty - Negligence;
  9. Inspectors and enforcement;
  10. Offences, Self Incrimination and Defences;
  11. Fair Work Act and Protections

learning_activities.topic:
Preparation for Moot Court Exercise and Moot Court

These workshops will firstly prepare students for the Moot Court exercise which involves a detailed hypothetical OHS legal case. Students will be provided with the facts of the case, relevant materials and important concepts will be discussed. Students will be allocated a task and required to research the issues related to their allocated task. This preparation will be applied to the Moot Court which involves student oral presentations (role plays) in a simulated court and a debrief of the exercise.
